title: What Matters This Week in the 2020 Race
text:
Early this week, Sen. Elizabeth Warren held a rally in New York, a state that is nearly impossible for Democrats to lose. On the same day, President Trump held a rally in New Mexico, a state that will be hard for Republicans to win.

Those moves reveal much about how the two parties see next year’s presidential race.

For Mr. Trump and his re-election campaign, a high priority is to find some states he lost in 2016 that he has at least some chance of flipping his way next year, in case Democrats manage to reclaim key states such as Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan that went Mr. Trump’s way last time.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS Which moment this past week has stuck with you and what do you hope the 2020 race brings this coming week? Join the conversation below.

The list of such states isn’t long, but New Mexico is one, which is why Mr. Trump was there Monday. Mr. Trump lost New Mexico to Democrat Hillary Clinton by 8 percentage points in 2016—but Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson, a former New Mexico governor, picked up nine points, suggesting to Team Trump there is room for an upset.

The other states on the Trump list of potential flips are New Hampshire, Nevada and Minnesota—and the president has visited them all in recent months.

Meanwhile, many Democrats, including in Ms. Warren’s camp, instead see the priority in the 2020 race as energizing and turning out the Democratic base. If that happens, they believe, higher Democratic excitement and turnout will hold all the states Mrs. Clinton won and flip some Trump states the Democrats will need to win in the Electoral College.

Thus, Ms. Warren was in solidly blue New York for a giant outdoor rally—and to pose for many photos with supporters. The idea was to both demonstrate and generate excitement in the liberal Democratic base.

A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed just how important that liberal base is to the Warren campaign. While she continues to trail former Vice President Joe Biden overall among all Democratic voters, 31% to 25%, she is easily the top choice among those who identify themselves as liberals.

Amid the maneuvering, of course, the key early states of Iowa and New Hampshire are never far from candidates’ minds, as will be clear when Democrats flock to Iowa Saturday for the state’s traditional party steak fry.

Write to Gerald F. Seib at jerry.seib@wsj.com
description: Early this week, Sen. Elizabeth Warren held a rally in New York, a state that is nearly impossible for Democrats to lose. On the same day, President Trump held a rally in New Mexico, a state that will be hard for Republicans to win. Those moves reveal much about how the two parties see next year’s presidential race.
